## Background

# What is ChIP-seq?


- ChIP-seq = High-throughput sequencing + chromatin immunoprecipitation
- Produces millions of short DNA reads that are enriched for DNA-protein interactions


![chipseqoverview](assets/img/image1.png)
Huber et al, 2006

# What does ChIP-seq look like?

- Distribution of paired-end reads from ChIP-seq data to estimate fragment size

![chipseqfragments](assets/img/image2.png)

## Background

# What does ChIP-seq look like?

**Noisey!**

- The distribution of the ChIP-seq reads is noisy and depends on the protocol and sequencing depth

```{r echo=FALSE,message=FALSE,fig.width=12,fig.height=5,warning=FALSE,results='hide'}
require(ProjectTemplate)
od<-setwd('..')
load.project()

plot(macswiggle[[1]]$control$chr01$V1,macswiggle[[1]]$control$chr01$V2,'l',col=1,xlab="Chr01 position",ylab="Number of ChIP-seq tags overlapping position",ylim=c(0,80))
lines(macswiggle[[1]]$treat$chr01$V1,macswiggle[[1]]$treat$chr01$V2,col="#AA2222AA")
title('Distribution of ChIP-seq and control reads (Chr01)')
setwd(od)
```

## Overview 
# ChIP-seq applications

- ChIP-seq itself is an "application" of next-gen sequencing
-- Investigate transcription factor binding sites
-- histone modifications
-- regulatory motifs
- Important to compare data to find important differences
- Combine with gene expression data to find gene regulatory networks

![regulatorynetwork](assets/img/image4.gif)
From http://genome.tbdb.org/annotation/genome/tbdb/RegulatoryNetwork.html
